Environments

Arena class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Arena(agents: List[Agent], x_left: float, x_right: float, y_top: float, y_bottom: float, keep_out=False)[source]

A class to represent a rectangular arena, which will confine any agents which are inside of its walls and in its list.

__init__(agents: List[Agent], x_left: float, x_right: float, y_top: float, y_bottom: float)[source]

Note: in the current implementation, the code does not check that x_right > x_left and y_top > y_bottom - you have to make sure you get this right yourself.

Parameters:

  • agents (List of Agent) – List of agents which are confined or kept out by the Arena’s walls. Agents must have a radius attribute for Arena to work.

  • x_left (float) – The x-coordinate of the arena’s left wall.

  • x_right (float) – The x-coordinate of the arena’s right wall.

  • y_top (float) – The y-coordinate of the arena’s top wall.

  • y_bottom (float) – The y-coordinate of the arena’s bottom wall.

  • keep_out (bool) – A flag to determine whether the arena keeps agents in (for False) or out (for True). Defaults to False.

draw(ax) → None[source]

A method to draw an Arena on Matplotlib axes.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the Arena on.

draw2() → None[source]

A method to draw an Arena on a Matplotlib figure. If there is no figure already open, a new one will be opened. If there is already one or more figure open, then the arena will be drawn on the last one used.

get_data()[source]

A function to get the data from an Arena, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from System: see System

  • arena left x-co-ordinate: data["x_left"]

  • arena right x-co-ordinate: data["x_right"]

  • arena top y-co-ordinate: data["y_top"]

  • arena bottom y-co-ordinate: data["y_bottom"]

  • keep_out flag: data["keep_out"]

Returns:

The System’s data.

Return type:

dict

line_drawer(x1: float, x2: float, y1: float, y2: float, screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float) → None[source]

A method for drawing a straight line between two points on a PyGame display.

Parameters:

  • x1 (float) – The x-coordinate of the first point.

  • x2 (float) – The x-coordinate of the second point.

  • y1 (float) – The y-coordinate of the first point.

  • y2 (float) – The y-coordinate of the second point.

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

move(x_move: float, y_move: float) → None[source]

A method which can be used to move an Arena by the distance specified in the x and y dimensions. This method would normally be called from an Arena’s step method.

Parameters:

  • x_move (float) – The distance to move the Arena by in the x-axis.

  • y_move (float) – The distance to move the Arena by in the y-axis.

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float)[source]

A method for drawing an Arena on a PyGame display.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset()[source]

Reset an Arena to its original state upon its construction, e.g. so that it can be re-used in another simulation run.

step(dt: float, x_move: float = None, y_move: float = None) → None[source]

Step Arena forwards in time. If any Agent s in its agents list have crossed its walls, they will be pushed back inside.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the Arena over. Currently unused here.

  • x_move (float) – The distance to move the Arena by in the x-axis.

  • y_move (float) – The distance to move the Arena by in the y-axis.

CircularArena class

class Sandbox_V1_4.CircularArena(agents: List[Agent], x: float, y: float, radius: float, keep_out=False)[source]

A class to represent a circular arena, which will confine any agents which are inside of its walls and in its list.

__init__(agents: List[Agent], x_left: float, x_right: float, y_top: float, y_bottom: float)[source]
Parameters:

  • agents (List of Agent) – List of agents which are confined or kept out by the CircularArena’s wall. Agents must have a radius attribute for CircularArena to work.

  • x_left (float) – The x-coordinate of the arena’s centre.

  • x_right (float) – The x-coordinate of the arena’s centre.

  • radius (float) – The arena’s radius.

  • keep_out (bool) – A flag to determine whether the arena keeps agents in (for False) or out (for True). Defaults to False.

draw(ax) → None[source]

A method to draw a CircularArena on Matplotlib axes.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the Arena on.

draw2() → None[source]

A method to draw a CircularArena on a Matplotlib figure. If there is no figure already open, a new one will be opened. If there is already one or more figure open, then the arena will be drawn on the last one used.

get_data()[source]

A function to get the data from a CircularArena, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from System: see System

  • arena radius: data["radius"]

  • keep_out flag: data["keep_out"]

Returns:

The System’s data.

Return type:

dict

get_points(n=180)[source]

A method to generate the coordinates for approximating the arena’s circular form with straight line segments.

move(x_move: float, y_move: float) → None[source]

A method which can be used to move an CircularArena by the distance specified in the x and y dimensions. This method would normally be called from an CircularArena’s step method.

Parameters:

  • x_move (float) – The distance to move the CircularArena by in the x-axis.

  • y_move (float) – The distance to move the CircularArena by in the y-axis.

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float)[source]

A method for drawing aa CircularArena on a PyGame display.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset()[source]

Reset a CircularArena to its original state upon its construction, e.g. so that it can be re-used in another simulation run.

step(dt: float, x_move: float = None, y_move: float = None) → None[source]

Step CircularArena forwards in time. If any Agent s in its agents list have crossed its walls, they will be pushed back inside.

Parameters:

  • dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the CircularArena over. Currently unused here.

  • x_move (float) – The distance to move the CircularArena by in the x-axis.

  • y_move (float) – The distance to move the CircularArena by in the y-axis.

PheromoneManager class

class Sandbox_V1_4.PheromoneManager(pheromones=[], decay_rate=0.01)[source]

A class for managing the decay of a list of PheromoneSource objects.

__init__(pheromones=[], decay_rate=0.01)[source]
Parameters:

  • pheromones (list(PheromoneSource)) – Defaults to an empty list.

  • decay_rate (float) – The rate at which all pheromones managed by an instance of this class will decay by. In every simulation step, the amount of pheromone in each PheromoneSource in the pheromones list decays by dt * decay_rate, until the point when the pheromone’s level falls below 0 and the PheromoneSource is deleted. Defaults to 0.01.

add_pheromone(p)[source]

A method for adding an existing PheromoneSource to the pheromones list.

Parameters:

p (PheromoneSource) – The PheromoneSource to add to the list.

add_pheromone_at(x, y)[source]

A method for adding a PheromoneSource at the given coordinates.

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate to add the pheromone source at.

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate to add the pheromone source at.

draw(ax)[source]

A method to draw all the instances of PheromoneSource belonging to a PheromoneManager on Matplotlib axes.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the Arena on.

pygame_draw(screen, scale, shiftx, shifty)[source]

A method to draw all the instances of PheromoneSource belonging to a PheromoneManager on a PyGame display.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset()[source]

Reset a PheromoneManager to its original state upon its construction, e.g. so that it can be re-used in another simulation run.

step(dt)[source]

Step PheromoneManager forwards in time.

Every PheromoneSource belonging to the PheromoneManager will decay, and vanish if completely depleted.

Parameters:

dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the pheromones over. Currently unused here.

Consumable class

class Sandbox_V1_4.Consumable(x, y, radius=0.5, quantity=10, recovery_time=10, colour='green')[source]

A class to implement a consumable item, which can either give or take energy from a system which consumes it. In this way, it can be used to model, in a very simple way, the effects of food or toxins (poison).

A Consumable has a LightSource attached to it, and so can be detected by an agent’s light sensors.

__init__(self, x, y, radius=0.5, quantity=10, recovery_time=10, colour='green')[source]
Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate of the consumable.

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate of the consumable.

  • radius (float) – An agent which is set up to “eat” instances of Consumable will consume one if it passes within this distance of its position. Defaults to 0.5.

  • quantity (float) – The amount of energy which a Consumable will add to or remove from an agent which consumes it. Positive quantities will increase the agent’s energy level, like food, while negative quantities will drain the agent’s energy, like (a potentially mild) toxin, or poison. Defaults to 10.

  • recovery_time (float) – The time it takes for a consumable to be replenished (e.g. by growing back) after it has been consumed. If you would prefer for it not to ever grow back, then make this number larger than the duration of your simulation. Defaults to 10.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the consumable’s attached light source. Needs to be a value which PyGame (and potentially Matplotlib) will recognise. Defaults to "green".

consume()[source]

A method to implement the consumption of a Consumable. If the consumable is already depleted, nothing happens. Otherwise, it will be depleted, and the light source attached to it will be switched off until it is replenished.

draw(ax)[source]

A method to draw a Consumable on Matplotlib axes. If the Consumable is currently “full” it will be drawn with full opacity. If it is currently in a depleted, or consumed, state then it will be drawn with only 30% opacity.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the Arena on.

get_data()[source]

A function to get the data from a Consumable, in the form of a string-keyed dict.

These data, as and when they are included in the returned dict, can be accessed with the following keys:

  • data inherited from System: see System

  • data from the attached LightSource: data["light_source"]

  • the history of when the consumable is/isn’t depleted: data["depleteds"]

pygame_draw(screen, scale, shiftx, shifty)[source]

A method for drawing a Consumable on a PyGame display. If the Consumable is currently “full” it will be drawn as a filled circle. If it is currently in a depleted, or consumed, state then it will be drawn as an unfilled circle.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

reset() → None[source]

Reset a Consumable to its original state upon its construction, e.g. so that it can be re-used in another simulation run.

step(dt)[source]

A method to step a Consumable forwards in time. If the consumable has been depleted, then this method uses a time to determine when it should become replenished.

Parameters:

dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the Consumable over.

FloorPatch class

class Sandbox_V1_4.FloorPatch(x_left: float, x_right: float, y_top: float, y_bottom: float, colour: str = 'grey', label: str = 'grey')[source]

A class to represent a rectangular coloured patch on the ground.

__init__(self, x_left: float, x_right: float, y_top: float, y_bottom: float, colour: str = 'grey', label: str = 'grey')[source]
Parameters:

  • x_left (float) – The left edge x-coordinate of the patch.

  • x_right (float) – The right edge x-coordinate of the patch.

  • y_top (float) – The top edge y-coordinate of the patch.

  • y_bottom (float) – The bottom edge y-coordinate of the patch.

  • colour (str) – The colour of the patch, for drawing.

  • label (str) – The label of the patch. Only sensors with the same label, or None as their label, can potentially detect this patch.

draw(ax) → None[source]

A method to draw a FloorPatch on Matplotlib axes.

Parameters:

ax (Matplotlib axes) – The Matplotlib axes to draw the Arena on.

is_in(x: float, y: float) → bool[source]

A method to determine whether the passed in coordiante lies within the patch. Used for sensing.

Parameters:

  • x (float) – The x-coordinate to check (e.g. of a sensor)

  • y (float) – The y-coordinate to check (e.g. of a sensor)

pygame_draw(screen, scale: float, shiftx: float, shifty: float)[source]

A method for drawing a FloorPatch on a PyGame display.

Parameters:

  • screen (PyGame display) – The PyGame display to draw on.

  • scale (float) – The scale to draw at.

  • shiftx (float) – The offset from centre in the x-axis for drawing.

  • shifty (float) – The offset from centre in the y-axis for drawing.

MerryGoRound class

class Sandbox_V1_4.MerryGoRound(light_sources, period, is_on_ind=0)[source]

A class to simulate a single light which “moves” along a predefined path. Actually, this class operates on a list of light sources, and emulates the movement of one of them by changing which single light is on at any given time. This class could be used in other ways, but only works as intended if the list of lights is organised correctly, e.g. when the list of lights creates a circular path.

__init__(self, light_sources, period, is_on_ind=0)[source]
Parameters:

  • light_sources (list(LightSource)) – The list of light sources used by the MerryGoRound.

  • period (float) – The time taken for the light which is switched on to change.

  • is_on_ind (int) – The index in the list of light sources of the light which is initially switched on. Defaults to 0.

reset()[source]

Reset merry go round, so it can be reused in later simulation runs.

step(dt)[source]

Step MerryGoRound forward in time.

Parameters:

dt (float) – The interval of time to integrate the controller over.

Environment builders

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.random_sources(x_min=-10, x_max=10, y_min=-10, y_max=10, brightness=1, n=20, colour='yellow', label='yellow')[source]

A function which generates n lights at random coordinates in the rectangular region specifed by the x-interval [x_min, x_max] and the y-interval [y_min, y_max]. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.sources_circle(n=20, r=9, x=0, y=0, brightness=1, label: str = None, colour='yellow')[source]

A function to generate a circular arrangment of n lights, with radius r. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.sources_ellipse(n=20, a=9, b=12, x=0, y=0, brightness=1, label: str = None, colour='yellow')[source]

A function to generate an elliptical arrangment of n lights, with width = 2a and height = 2b. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.sources_horizontal_line(x_min, x_max, y, n, brightness=1, label: str = None, colour='yellow')[source]

A function which generates n lights along the horizontal line which connects the coordinates [x_min, y] and [x_max, y]. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.sources_line(x1, y1, x2, y2, n, brightness=1, label: str = None, colour='yellow')[source]

A function which generates n lights along the line which connects the coordinates [x1, y1] and [x2, y2]. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.sources_rectangle(x_n=10, y_n=10, x=0, y=0, width=20, height=20, brightness=1, label: str = None, colour='yellow')[source]

A function to generate a rectangular arrangement of lights, with x_n lights in the x-axis and y_n lights in the y-axis. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_features.sources_vertical_line(x, y_min, y_max, n, brightness=1, label: str = None, colour='yellow')[source]

A function which generates n lights along the vertical line which connects the coordinates [x, y_min] and [x, y_max]. See Sandbox_V1_3.LightSource for explanations of the light properties brightness, label and color.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_builder.an_EBA_arena(x_left, x_right, y_bottom, y_top, n1, n2, arena_agents=[], brightness=1)[source]

A function to generate two sets of randomly arranged lights, and an Sandbox_V1_3.Arena. There will be n1 yellow lights and n2 red lights. Uses Sandbox_V1_3.factories.environment_features.random_sources.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_builder.circle_with_arena(radius, num, x_left, x_right, y_bottom, y_top, arena_agents=[], brightness=1)[source]

A function to generate a circular arrangement of lights, centred on x=0, y=0, and an Sandbox_V1_3.Arena Uses Sandbox_V1_3.factories.environment_features.sources_circle.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_builder.double_circle(x1, y1, rad1, num1, x2, y2, rad2, num2)[source]

A function to generate two circular arrangements of lights, centred one yellow and one red. Uses Sandbox_V1_3.factories.environment_features.sources_circle.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_builder.ellipse_with_arena(a, b, num, x_left, x_right, y_bottom, y_top, arena_agents=[], brightness=1)[source]

A function to generate an elliptical arrangement of lights, centred on x=0, y=0, and an Sandbox_V1_3.Arena Uses Sandbox_V1_3.factories.environment_features.sources_ellipse.

Sandbox_V1_4.factories.environment_builder.rect_with_arena(x_left, x_right, y_bottom, y_top, x_n, y_n, width, height, arena_agents=[], brightness=1)[source]

A function to generate a rectangular arrangement of lights, centred on x=0, y=0, and an Sandbox_V1_3.Arena Uses Sandbox_V1_3.factories.environment_features.sources_rectangle.
